physicalObject: silver Apple iMac all-in-one computer with stand
proxyLocation: top left of the primary desk
utilizationMethod: Pinch the lower right metal corner of the monitor frame between thumb and index finger while supporting the back of the stand with the middle finger, then move the wrist so the corner projects forward like fork tines

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A fork is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape about 0.8-1 inch wide, and roughly 2-3mm thick.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will pick the fork up from the table with a lateral or precision pinch—thumb pressing against one side of the handle while the index finger curls on the opposite side and the middle finger supports underneath. The grip point is toward the rear half of the handle (about 10‒12 cm from the tips), allowing the tines to point forward. Typical motions are wrist-driven pronation/supination to orient the tines, small vertical stabs to spear food, and short radial/ulnar deviations when assisting a knife. Because the fork is thin (≈2 mm) and rigid stainless steel, the hand feels a smooth, cool, hard outline with almost no compliance. Inertia is minimal, so the utensil follows hand movements immediately; only the narrow tines offer faint vibratory feedback when they contact the plate or food.

The grip point is toward the rear half of the handle (about 10‒12 cm from the tips), allowing the tines to point forward. Typical motions are wrist-driven pronation/supination to orient the tines, small vertical stabs to spear food, and short radial/ulnar deviations when assisting a knife. Because the fork is thin (≈2 mm) and rigid stainless steel, the hand feels a smooth, cool, hard outline with almost no compliance. Inertia is minimal, so the utensil follows hand movements immediately; only the narrow tines offer faint vibratory feedback when they contact the plate or food.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A knife is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape about 0.8-1 inch wide, and roughly 2-3mm thick.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The dinner knife is grasped in a modified power grip: the handle rests against the palm while the thumb and middle/ring fingers wrap around; the index finger often extends along the spine for guidance. Users lift it, translate it over the plate, then perform sawing motions—short fore–aft strokes combined with slight downward pressure—while the wrist remains relatively locked. They may also rotate the knife 90° and drag it to spread butter. The blade is thin, smooth, and rigid, so the user feels a flat cool edge with no give. The knife’s low mass produces light but noticeable inertial resistance during rapid sawing; plate contact returns subtle vibrations that confirm cutting progress.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A spoon is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape about 0.8-1 inch wide, and roughly 2-3mm thick.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users employ a precision pinch like a pen grip, holding the handle between thumb and index finger with the bowl facing upward. Movements include dipping the bowl into food, scooping by curling the wrist, and lifting toward the mouth with a gentle supination to keep contents level. When stirring liquids, they roll the utensil between fingertips, causing small circular wrist motions. The spoon’s bowl adds momentary weight once filled, so users sense a brief increase in inertia. Haptically, they feel a smooth, continuous concave surface transitioning into a narrow, flat handle—cool, metallic, and rigid throughout.

The exterior feels uniformly hard with slight texture variation at the cap’s ridges and remains at room temperature.
